questions.text: A 59-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of a progressively enlarging, 8-mm skin lesion on the right shoulder that developed 1 month ago. The patient has a light-skinned complexion and has had several dysplastic nevi removed in the past. A photograph of the lesion is shown. The lesion is most likely derived from cells that are also the embryological origin of which of the following tumors?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Neuroblastomas are tumors derived from chromaffin cells of the adrenal medulla that, like melanomas, originate from neural crest cells. Other notable derivatives of neural crest cells include Schwann cells, facial cartilage, the aorticopulmonary septum, and odontoblasts.

Neuroblastomas are tumors of infancy that most commonly manifest as a firm, irregular abdominal mass that causes distention and pain.
Image Description:

CT abdomen (with oral and IV contrast; axial plane)

A large heterogeneous mass (green overlay) with little to no vascular enhancement is present in the area of the right adrenal gland.

This is a common CT appearance of adrenal neuroblastoma. Although not present on this CT, accompanying calcifications are common.

B) INCORRECT:

Liposarcomas arise from adipocytes in deep soft tissue. These cells originate from mesoderm, not neural crest cells.

C) INCORRECT:

Medullary thyroid cancer arises from parafollicular cells of the thyroid. Though previously thought to originate from neural crest cells, these cells actually originate from endoderm.

D) INCORRECT:

Adrenal adenomas are tumors of the adrenal cortex, which originates from mesoderm, not neural crest cells. The adrenal medulla originates from neural crest cells.

E) INCORRECT:

Basal cell carcinomas arise from keratinocytes of the epidermis. These cells originate from surface ectoderm, not neural crest cells.

F) INCORRECT:

Ectocervical cancers arise from squamous cells of the epithelium. These cells originate from surface ectoderm, not neural crest cells.
questions.hint: The lesion in the photograph is asymmetric, irregularly bordered, variegated in color, > 6 mm in diameter, and developed recently. All of these features, in combination with a history of dysplastic nevi, are concerning for melanoma, which is a malignant tumor of melanocytes. These cells originate from neural crest cells.

questions.text: A 78-year-old man comes to the physician because of a change in his voice. His wife says his voice has progressively become higher pitched, and he has had a 5.4-kg (11.9-lb) weight loss over the past 4 months. He has smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 40 years. Direct laryngoscopy shows an irregular, nodular glottic mass. A biopsy specimen of the mass shows poorly differentiated squamous cells with nuclear atypia, hyperkeratosis, and disruption of the basement membrane. Involvement of a muscle derived from which of the following pharyngeal arches is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The 6th pharyngeal arch gives rise to the intrinsic muscles of the larynx, with the exception of the cricothyroid muscle. These muscles are responsible for the opening and closing of the glottis, the relaxation of the vocal cords that allows pitch lowering, and fine adjustments to the vocal cords, which are important for phonation. This patient's increased pitch in voice is most likely due to cricothyroid muscle involvement, which is derived from a different pharyngeal arch.

B) INCORRECT:

The 2ndpharyngeal arch gives rise to the muscles of facial expression, stapedius (control of sound amplitude), stylohyoid (elevation of the hyoid), platysma (facial expression, jaw depression), and posterior belly of the digastric (jaw opening).

C) INCORRECT:

The 1st pharyngeal arch gives rise to the muscles of mastication, mylohyoid (elevation of the tongue, depression of the mandible), anterior belly of the digastric (jaw opening), tensor tympani (tensing of the tympanic membrane), and the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.

D) INCORRECT:

The 3rd pharyngeal arch gives rise to the stylopharyngeus muscle, which elevates the larynx and pharynx during swallowing. Other structures that derive from the 3rd pharyngeal arch include the glossopharyngeal nerve and the greater horn of the hyoid bone.

E) CORRECT:

The 4th pharyngeal arch gives rise to the cricothyroid muscle as well as most muscles responsible for pharyngeal constriction. Contraction of the cricothyroid muscle causes vocal cord contraction, which controls pitch elevation. Involvement of the cricothyroid muscle should be suspected in any patient with changes in vocal pitch.
Image Description:

Clockwise from top left: nerve, skeletal structure, muscle, and artery derivatives of the pharyngeal arches.
questions.hint: Laryngeal carcinoma has caused this patient's voice to become high-pitched. The pitch of the voice is heightened by contraction of the vocal cords. This function is carried out by the cricothyroid muscle.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of a neck mass and hoarseness. He has no history of major medical illness. Physical examination shows a 2.5-cm fixed, irregular thyroid nodule. His serum calcitonin concentration is elevated. The nodule is most likely composed of cells that are embryologically derived from which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The paired inferior parathyroid glands are derived from the third branchial pouch. The parathyroids produce PTH, which is elevated in primary hyperparathyroidism. Elevated PTH levels cause hypercalcemia, which results in a compensatory increase in serum calcitonin. However, primary hyperparathyroidism most commonly occurs due to a parathyroid adenoma, which is rarely palpable and would not manifest with hoarseness or a fixed mass.

B) INCORRECT:

Derivatives of the fourth branchial arch include the cartilage of the larynx, several muscles of the larynx and pharynx, and the superior laryngeal branch of the vagus nerve. None of these structures secrete or influence the secretion of calcitonin, which is elevated in this case.

C) CORRECT:

The two lateral thyroid anlagen differentiate from ultimobranchial bodies, the most caudal, or ultimate, structures derived from the fourth branchial pouch. The lateral anlagen then fuse with the median thyroid anlage to form the thyroid gland. The parafollicular C cells are thought to be derived from the endoderm of the lateral thyroid anlage and secrete calcitonin. Medullary thyroid cancer arises from these cells and can manifest as a firm, painless thyroid nodule, as well as hoarseness and elevated serum calcitonin levels, which are all seen in this case. The findings of recent experimental studies argue strongly against the previous hypothesis that parafollicular C cells are derived from the neural crest.

The endodermal cells of the median thyroid anlage differentiate into thyroid follicular cells.

D) INCORRECT:

The surface ectoderm gives rise to the epidermis, hair, nails, inner ear, external ear, enamel of teeth, lens of the eyes, anterior pituitary, parotid gland, and the anal canal (below the pectinate line). Although a tumor of the epidermis could manifest as a neck mass, it would not be expected to cause elevated serum calcitonin.

E) INCORRECT:

The cells of the second branchial pouch differentiate into the epithelial tissue lining the tonsils. Since the deep cervical lymph nodes receive lymphatic drainage from the tonsils, tonsillitis or lymphoma in the area could manifest as cervical lymphadenopathy. However, an alteration in serum calcitonin levels would not be expected.
questions.hint: This patient's hoarseness and fixed, irregular thyroid nodule should raise concern for invasive thyroid cancer. His elevated calcitonin suggests medullary carcinoma of the thyroid, a tumor derived from parafollicular C cells.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation prior to parathyroidectomy. A Tc99m-sestamibi scan for parathyroid tissue shows two spots of increased uptake in the superior mediastinum. These spots represent structures that are most likely derived from which of the following embryological precursors?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The 4th branchial pouch differentiates into the superior parathyroid glands. During embryological development, the superior parathyroid glands do not move as far caudally as the inferior parathyroid glands and therefore come to rest on the posterior side of each superior pole of the thyroid lobes. Ectopic parathyroid glands that are located caudally in the mediastinum usually arise from a different location.

B) CORRECT:

The derivatives of the 3rd branchial pouch include the inferior parathyroid glands and the thymus. The primordial inferior parathyroid glands are connected to the primordial thymus. Normally, the tissue connecting the thymus and inferior parathyroid glands degenerates by the time the inferior parathyroid glands reach the lower poles of the thyroid gland. If this tissue does not degenerate, the inferior parathyroid glands descend along with the thymus, which continues to migrate into the superior mediastinum. Because of this relatively long course of descent, the location of the inferior parathyroid glands is more variable and can be found anywhere between the inferior poles of the thyroid lobes and the superior mediastinum. Therefore, the ectopic mediastinal parathyroid tissue seen on the Tc99m-sestamibi scan is most likely to be a derivative of the 3rd branchial pouch. Despite originating caudally in the 4th branchial pouch, the superior parathyroid glands attach themselves to the developing thyroid gland and come to rest on the posterior side of each superior pole of the thyroid lobes.

C) INCORRECT:

The cartilaginous component of the second branchial arch differentiates into the stapes, styloid process of the temporal bone, lesser horn of the hyoid bone, and the stylohyoid ligament. The muscular component differentiates into the muscles of facial expression, the stapedius, stylohyoid, platysma, and the posterior belly of the digastric. The parathyroid glands are not derived from the second branchial arch.

D) INCORRECT:

The 2nd branchial pouch differentiates into the epithelial lining of the tonsils. The parathyroid glands are not derived from the 2ndbranchial pouch.

E) INCORRECT:

The cartilaginous component of the fourth branchial arch differentiates into the thyroid, cricoid, corniculate, cuneiform, and arytenoid cartilages. The muscular component differentiates into the pharyngeal constrictor, cricothyroid, and levator veli palatini muscles. The parathyroid glands are not derived from the fourth branchial arch.

F) INCORRECT:

The cartilaginous component of the third branchial arch differentiates into the greater horn of the hyoid bone. The muscular component differentiates into the stylopharyngeus. The parathyroid glands are not derived from the third branchial arch.
questions.hint: Hyperfunctioning parathyroid glands take up Tc99m-sestamibi and show up as hotspots on a scan, as seen here. The inferior parathyroid glands arise from the same embryological precursor as the thymus.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-day history of right-sided facial weakness and sound intolerance. Three days ago, he hit the right side of his head in a motor vehicle collision. He neither lost consciousness nor sought medical attention. Physical examination shows drooping of the mouth and inability to lift the eyebrows on the right side. Sensation over the face is not impaired. Impedance audiometry shows an absence of the acoustic reflex in the right ear. Further evaluation is most likely to show paralysis of which of the following muscles?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The tensor tympani muscle, which dampens loud sounds such as chewing or thunder, is innervated by the mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve. Therefore, a facial nerve palsy would not cause paralysis of this muscle.

B) INCORRECT:

The stylopharyngeus muscle, which elevates the larynx and pharynx during swallowing, is derived from the 3rd branchial arch and innervated by the glossopharyngeal nerve. A facial nerve palsy would not cause paralysis of this muscle.

C) INCORRECT:

The cricothyroid muscle, which tenses and elongates the vocal cords, is derived from the 4th branchial arch and is innervated by the external portion of the superior laryngeal nerve. A facial nerve palsy would not cause paralysis of this muscle.

D) INCORRECT:

The anterior belly of the digastric muscle, which assists the posterior belly of the digastric muscle in jaw opening, is derived from the 1st branchial arch and is innervated by the mylohyoid nerve. A facial nerve palsy would not cause paralysis of this muscle.

E) CORRECT:

The stylohyoid muscle, which elevates the tongue and moves the hyoid bone backward during swallowing, develops from the 2nd branchial arch. Therefore, facial nerve palsy causes paralysis of this muscle. Other muscles that are derived from the 2nd branchial arch and, thus innervated by the facial nerve, include the facial muscles, platysma, posterior belly of the digastric, and stapedius. Stapedius involvement is demonstrated in this case by hyperacusis with absent acoustic reflex.
Image Description:

Clockwise from top left: nerve, skeletal structure, muscle, and artery derivatives of the pharyngeal arches.
questions.hint: Asymmetric facial weakness and hyperacusis with an absent acoustic reflex indicate palsy of the facial nerve, which innervates structures derived from the 2nd branchial arch. An undisplaced temporal bone fracture can result in delayed-onset facial nerve palsy due to edema that leads to nerve compression.

questions.text: A 3175-g (7-lb) male newborn is delivered at 39 weeks' gestation to a 29-year-old primigravid woman following a spontaneous vaginal delivery. Apgar scores are 8 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. Cardiac examination in the delivery room shows a continuous machine-like murmur. An echocardiogram shows a structure with blood flow between the pulmonary artery and the aorta. This structure is most likely a derivate of which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The 4th aortic arch develops into the aortic arch on the left and the proximal part of the right subclavian artery on the right. The ductus arteriosus does not develop from the 4th aortic arch.

B) INCORRECT:

The 2nd aortic arch develops into the stapedial artery and the hyoid artery. The ductus arteriosus does not develop from the 2ndaortic arch.

C) CORRECT:

The 6th aortic arch is the origin of the proximal parts of the left and right pulmonary arteries and the ductus arteriosus (on the left side only).
Image Description:

The aortic arches develop in craniocaudal order, with the first two arches obliterating early. Not shown: a remnant of the first aortic arch forms part of the maxillary artery, and a remnant of the second aortic arch forms the hyoid artery. The second arch also forms the stapedial artery, which typically regresses around week 10 of development.

The third aortic arch gives rise to the common carotid and proximal internal carotid.

On the right, the fourth aortic arch gives rise to the proximal right subclavian artery. On the left, the fourth aortic arch gives rise to a portion of the aortic arch from left common carotid to left subclavian.

The fifth aortic arch either never develops or obliterates without giving rise to a vessel.

On the right, the sixth aortic arch gives rise to the right pulmonary artery. On the left, the sixth aortic arch gives rise to the left pulmonary artery and ductus arteriosus.

D) INCORRECT:

The 1st aortic arch is the origin of the maxillary artery. The ductus arteriosus does not develop from the 1st aortic arch.

E) INCORRECT:

The 3rd aortic arch develops into the common carotid artery and proximal part of the internal carotid artery. The ductus arteriosus does not develop from the 3rd aortic arch.
questions.hint: This newborn's examination shows a structure between the pulmonary artery and aorta with a continuous machine-like murmur heard on cardiac auscultation. This is characteristic of a patent ductus arteriosus.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman comes to the physician because she has not had a menstrual period for 5 weeks. Menarche was at the age of 14 years and menses occurred at regular 30-day intervals. She reports having unprotected sexual intercourse 3 weeks ago. A urine pregnancy test is positive. Which of the following best describes the stage of development of the embryo at this time?

choices.text: Sexual differentiation has begun, but fetal movement has not started
Fetal heart is beating, but cardiac activity is not yet visible on ultrasound
Limb buds have formed, but fetal movements have not begun
Neural crest has formed, but limb buds have not yet formed
Implantation has occured, but notochord has not yet formed

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sexual differentiation begins by week 10 of development. Fetal movement begins in week 8. This patient's embryo is most likely in week 3 of development; neither sexual differentiation nor fetal movement is likely to have begun at this time.

B) INCORRECT:

Fetal heart formation begins early in the mesoderm of the trilaminar embryonic disc as a paired tube in a developing pericardial cavity. The heart begins to beat in week 4 of development, but the heartbeat only becomes detectable on ultrasound around week 6. This patient's embryo is most likely in week 3 of development; the fetal heart is unlikely to be beating at this time.

C) INCORRECT:

The limb buds form during week 4 of development. Fetal movement begins in week 8. This patient's embryo is most likely in week 3 of development; the limb buds are unlikely to be fully formed at this time, and fetal movement is unlikely to have begun.

D) CORRECT:

Neurulation occurs during week 3 of embryonic development. During this process, the neural crest forms from the dorsal portion of the folded neural tube. Limb buds are structures of undifferentiated mesodermal cells that are sheathed by ectoderm. They form during week 4 of development and are unlikely to be present in this patient's embryo, which is most likely in week 3 of development.

E) INCORRECT:

Implantation, which refers to the adhesion of the developing embryo to the uterine endometrium, occurs approximately 1 week after fertilization. The notochord, which is a structure necessary for the differentiation of the neural tube epithelium, forms approximately 3 weeks after fertilization. An implanted embryo without a notochord would, therefore, be approximately 12 weeks old. This patient's embryo is most likely in week 3 of development.
questions.hint: Ovulation occurs 1216 days before the menstrual period, which coincides with the last time this patient had unprotected sexual intercourse. The embryo is, therefore, most likely in week 3 of development.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman comes to the physician because of intermittent pain in her neck, right shoulder, and arm, as well as a tingling sensation in her right hand. She first noticed her symptoms after she got off a rollercoaster ride 2 months ago. Physical examination shows weakness when extending the right wrist against resistance. An MRI of the head and neck is shown. This patient's condition is most likely the result of nerve root compression by a structure derived from which of the following embryologic layers?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Endoderm gives rise to the epithelial linings of most of the body. A spinal disk herniation, however, is caused by prolapse of the nucleus pulposus which develops from a different embryologic layer.

B) INCORRECT:

Neural crest cells give rise to Schwann cells and other neurons and glial cells of the peripheral nervous system. Disorders of these cells would lead to neurocutaneous syndromes like neurofibromatosis and tuberous sclerosis or tumors like neuroblastoma. These diseases would not be associated with spinal nerve root compression, as seen in this patient. A spinal disk herniation is caused by prolapse of the nucleus pulposus which develops from a different embryologic layer.

C) CORRECT:

The nucleus pulposus is the only remnant of the notochord, the rod of mesoderm that is essential for the development of the overlying ectoderm into neuroectoderm and formation of the neural plate. Spinal disk herniation is caused by prolapse of the nucleus pulposus through a defect in the annulus fibrosus and beyond the margins of the vertebral body. It presents with radiculopathy, as seen in this patient.
Image Description:

Left: overview of the main embryonic structures at approx. day 18

Right: cross-sections of the embryonic disc at several heights, showing the neural fold, the neural crest, and the neural tube

D) INCORRECT:

The neural tube gives rise to the central nervous system, the retina, and the pineal gland. Neural tube defects lead to conditions like spina bifida, meningomyelocele, and anencephaly. A spinal disk herniation, however, is caused by prolapse of the nucleus pulposus, which develops from a different embryologic layer.

E) INCORRECT:

Surface ectoderm gives rise to the epidermis, hair, nails, inner ear, external ear, enamel of teeth, lens of the eyes, anterior pituitary, parotid gland, and anal canal (below the pectinate line). A spinal disk herniation, however, is caused by prolapse of the nucleus pulposus which develops from a different embryologic layer.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms are suggestive of cervical radiculopathy. The MRI confirms this as it shows a spinal disk herniation at C6C7.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of decreased hearing, dizziness, and ringing in his right ear for the past 6 months. Physical examination shows multiple soft, yellow plaques and papules on his arms, chest, and back. There is sensorineural hearing loss and weakness of facial muscles bilaterally. His gait is unsteady. An MRI of the brain shows a 3-cm mass near the right internal auditory meatus and a 2-cm mass at the left cerebellopontine angle. The abnormal cells in these masses are most likely derived from which of the following embryological structures?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The neural tube gives rise to CNS glial cells (e.g., oligodendrocytes, astrocytes, ependymal cells), which are the glial cells of CN I and CN II. The neural tube does not give rise to Schwann cells, which are the glial cells of cranial nerves IIIXII. Optic gliomas, which occur in neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1), are derived from astrocytes. NF1 can present similarly with cutaneous neurofibromas, but the absence of cafe-au-lait spots on physical examination and the presence of bilateral acoustic neuromas suggests a diagnosis of type 2 rather than NF1. NF2 is typically associated with optic nerve meningiomas rather than optic nerve gliomas.

B) INCORRECT:

The surface ectoderm gives rise to the anterior pituitary, external auditory canal, and inner ear structures (e.g., cochlea, vestibule, semicircular ducts) as well as glands of the skin, the parotid glands, and ameloblasts. It does not give rise to neurons or glial cells. Craniopharyngiomas arise from the remnant of the Rathke's pouch, which is a surface ectodermal derivative. They occur in the midline above the sella turcica and present typically during childhood with headache, bitemporal hemianopsia, and/or symptoms of hyperprolactinemia.

C) CORRECT:

Schwann cells are formed from neural crest cells, which arise from the lateral border of the neural plate (neuroectoderm) and migrate along somites to different parts of the body. Other structures derived from neural crest cells are neurons of cranial nerves III to XII, peripheral nerve neurons (both somatic and autonomic), skull bones, pia and arachnoid mater, odontoblasts, laryngeal cartilage, adrenal medulla, melanocytes, aorticopulmonary septum, and endocardial cushion. An immunohistochemical marker of neural crest cells is S-100, which is positive in melanomas, Langerhans cell histiocytosis, and schwannomas.

D) INCORRECT:

The notochord induces the formation of the neuroectoderm from the primitive ectoderm. The lateral border of the neuroectoderm will give rise to the embryological precursor of Schwann cells, but the notochord itself does not give rise to any neurological structure. It only forms the nucleus pulposus of the vertebral disc.

E) INCORRECT:

The mesoderm gives rise to bones, muscles (smooth, skeletal, and cardiac), connective tissue (including serosal linings of body cavities, e.g., peritoneum, pericardium, pleura) and dura mater), lymphatics, blood vessels, spleen, kidneys, adrenal cortex, and gonads. It does not form neurons or glial cells.
questions.hint: The bilateral masses in this patient causing sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and vertigo are acoustic neuromas, which arise from Schwann cells of CN VIII. Compression of the adjacent CN VII causes facial weakness. The combination of multiple cutaneous neurofibromas with bilateral acoustic neuromas is pathognomic of neurofibromatosis type 2.

questions.text: A  29-year-old primigravid woman at 18 weeks gestation comes to the physician for her first prenatal visit. She works as a paralegal and lives with her husband. Her current pregnancy was unexpected, and she did not take any prenatal medications or supplements. Physical examination shows a uterus 2 inches above the umbilicus. The concentration of -fetoprotein in the maternal serum and concentrations of both -fetoprotein and acetylcholinesterase in the amniotic fluid are elevated. Ultrasonography of the uterus shows an increased amniotic fluid volume. The fetus most likely has which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Holoprosencephaly results from failure of the embryonic prosencephalon to separate into two cerebral hemispheres, leading to brain malformation of varying severity as well as midline craniofacial defects. The etiology is thought to be multifactorial, including both genetic (e.g., trisomy 13, mutations in sonic hedgehog signaling pathway) and environmental (e.g., alcohol and retinoic acid exposure in utero) components. Holoprosencephaly can be diagnosed on prenatal ultrasonography and fetal MRI; however, polyhydramnios is not a characteristic finding. Moreover, this defect is not associated with increased -fetoprotein and acetylcholinesterase levels in the maternal serum or amniotic fluid.

B) INCORRECT:

Lissencephaly results from failure of neuronal cell migration, thereby inhibiting development of the gyri and sulci. This malformation is typically genetic but may also be caused by viral infections or insufficient intrauterine perfusion in early pregnancy. Lissencephaly is often diagnosed at birth or soon after via imaging; however, polyhydramnios on prenatal ultrasonography is not a characteristic finding. Moreover, lissencephaly is not associated with increased -fetoprotein and acetylcholinesterase levels in the maternal serum or amniotic fluid.

C) INCORRECT:

Spina bifida occulta is a neural tube defect (NTD) that results from failure of the caudal neuropore to close. Folate deficiency, which this patient likely has (lack of prenatal supplements), is associated with an increased risk of NTDs. However, spina bifida occulta is a closed NTD and would, therefore, not show increased -fetoprotein and acetylcholinesterase levels in the maternal serum or amniotic fluid. Moreover, this defect is not associated with polyhydramnios on prenatal ultrasonography. Spina bifida occulta is most commonly diagnosed postnatally based on typical cutaneous findings (i.e., small dimple or tuft of hair in the lumbosacral region).

D) INCORRECT:

Myelomeningocele is a neural tube defect (NTD) that results from failure of the caudal neuropore to close. Folate deficiency, which this patient likely has (lack of prenatal supplements), is associated with an increased risk of NTDs. Myelomeningocele is an open NTD that would show increased -fetoprotein and acetylcholinesterase levels in the maternal serum or amniotic fluid, as seen here. However, this defect is not associated with polyhydramnios but is rather diagnosed based on vertebral irregularities (e.g., U-shaped vertebral body, bulging of the fetal back) on prenatal ultrasonography.
Image Description:

Ultrasound of 21-week fetus (sagittal plane)

A myelomeningocele sac (green overlay) is identified at the lumbar region. The sac contains anechoic fluid and some solid neural elements.

T: thorax

E) CORRECT:

Anencephaly is a lethal neural tube defect (NTD) characterized by an open cranial vault and absence of the forebrain. The most important risk factor associated with NTDs is folate deficiency, either due to dietary shortage or the consumption of folic acid antagonists (e.g., valproate, carbamazepine). Because anencephaly is an open NTD that leaves the neural tube exposed, -fetoprotein (AFP) and acetylcholinesterase (AChE) can diffuse freely into the amniotic fluid and maternal serum. If both AFP and AChE are elevated in the amniotic fluid, fetal NTDs can be diagnosed with high accuracy, even if ultrasonography is inconclusive.
questions.hint: This fetus's condition results from failure of closure of the rostral neuropore during embryogenesis. The increased amniotic fluid volume (i.e., polyhydramnios) seen here is due to impaired fetal swallowing.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 26 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a routine prenatal visit. Physical examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 26-week gestation. Fetal ultrasonography shows a male fetus with a thick band constricting the right lower arm; the limb distal to the constrictive band cannot be visualized. The most likely condition is an example of which of the following embryological abnormalities?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Deformation is a morphogenetic error that arises after the embryonic period (> 8 weeks) in which an organ or structure fails to develop due to an extrinsic force. Examples of deformation include congenital talipes equinovarus, developmental dysplasia of the hip, and congenital torticollis, which are caused by mechanical forces (e.g., prolonged breech presentation, uterine crowding). The constriction band and autoamputation amniotic band syndrome seen in this patient are the results of extrinsic force, but they constitute the breakdown of previously normal fetal tissue rather than the failure of a structure to develop.

B) INCORRECT:

Agenesis is a morphogenetic error in which an organ or structure fails to develop as a result of the absence of primordial tissue. Examples include agenesis of the cerebellar vermis (Dandy-Walker syndrome), renal agenesis, thyroid agenesis, and Mullerian agenesis. Amniotic band syndrome is not caused by agenesis.

C) CORRECT:

Disruption, the cause of amniotic band syndrome, is an embryological abnormality in which there is a breakdown of previously normal fetal tissue. In amniotic band syndrome, a tear in the amnion of the amniotic sac exposes multiple loose fibrous strands called amniotic bands. These bands entangle and constrict parts of the fetus, causing the breakdown of structures that had previously developed normally. Severe constriction can result in autoamputation, as seen here.

See Abnormalities of morphogenesis table.
Image Description:

Partial congenital amputation of the digits is seen on the right hand of this infant. The third and fifth digits are particularly affected.

D) INCORRECT:

A malformation is a morphogenetic error in which an organ or structure fails to develop as a result of an intrinsic disruption. Malformation typically occurs during embryogenesis (3rd8th week of gestational age). An Arnold-Chiari malformation is an example of such an error. Amniotic band syndrome is not caused by a malformation.

E) INCORRECT:

Aplasia is a morphogenetic error in which an organ or structure fails to develop despite the presence of its primordial tissue. Examples include cutis aplasia and thymic aplasia in DiGeorge syndrome. Amniotic band syndrome is not caused by aplasia.
questions.hint: This fetus most likely has amniotic band syndrome with autoamputation of the right lower arm due to a constriction ring.

questions.text: A 2710-g (6-lb) female newborn is delivered at 37 weeks' gestation to a 26-year-old primigravid woman following a spontaneous vaginal delivery. The mother received routine prenatal care, which was unremarkable. Apgar scores are 7 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. Physical examination shows skin dimpling and a tuft of hair over the gluteal cleft. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Failure of which of the following embryological processes is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Failed closure of the rostral neuropore during neurulation causes anencephaly, which is characterized by an open cranial vault and absence or underdevelopment of the forebrain and large portions of the skull. Anencephaly is usually detected on routine prenatal ultrasound and laboratory studies (i.e., increased maternal serum -fetoprotein) and is incompatible with life.

B) INCORRECT:

Failure of neuronal cell migration from the ventricular zone to the cortical zone during weeks 1224 of gestation leads to lissencephaly, which is characterized by underdevelopment of cortical sulci and gyri of the brain. Lissencephaly typically manifests with microcephaly, craniofacial abnormalities, seizures, and hypotonia.

C) CORRECT:

Spina bifida is the incomplete fusion of vertebral arches (typically affecting the lower lumbar or sacral spine) that results from incomplete closure of the caudal neuropore during neurulation. Although spina bifida occulta is considered to be a neural tube defect, the spinal cord, meninges, and overlying skin remain intact. The skin overlying the defect may be dysplastic, manifesting as skin dimpling, a hair tuft, and/or lipoma. Spina bifida occulta is not usually detected on routine prenatal ultrasound, and maternal serum -fetoprotein is normal because the lesion is covered by skin. The condition does not manifest with neurological symptoms and may be an incidental finding on imaging later in life.

Meningocele, myelocele, and myelomeningocele are open neural tube defects that are characterized by the herniation of meningeal and/or neural tissue through the vertebral defect. Due to the exposure of the tissue to the surrounding environment (e.g., amniotic fluid), these conditions are usually associated with severe neurological deficits (e.g., lower limb paralysis, bowel and bladder incontinence) and can be detected on routine prenatal ultrasound and laboratory studies (i.e., increased maternal serum -fetoprotein).

D) INCORRECT:

Failed fusion of the neural folds during neurulation leads to myeloschisis, which is the most severe subtype of neural tube defects. Myeloschisis manifests with bare, exposed neural tissue that is not covered by meninges, bones, or skin. Additionally, features such as club foot, joint contractures, and flaccid paralysis are typical. Myeloschisis is usually detected on routine prenatal ultrasound or laboratory studies (i.e., increased maternal serum -fetoprotein).
questions.hint: Skin dimpling and hair tuft over the gluteal cleft suggest spina bifida occulta.

questions.text: A 2550-g (5 lb 10 oz) female newborn is delivered at term to a 27-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1. Labor and delivery were uncomplicated but the mother did not receive prenatal care. Examination of the newborn shows hypotonia in the lower extremities and a red, fleshy swelling without overlying skin in the lumbosacral region. Clear yellow fluid leaks from the superior margin of the swelling. Ultrasonography of the swelling shows a fluid-filled sac containing herniated neural tissue. Which of the following best explains the pathogenesis of this patient's condition?

choices.text: Nondisjunction of the neural tube and surface ectoderm
Cystic dilation in the central canal

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Myelomeningocele is a disorder of primary neurulation that results from the failure of the posterior (caudal) neuropore to close at 34 weeks' gestation. While myelomeningoceles can usually be detected on routine prenatal ultrasound or laboratory studies (i.e., serum -fetoprotein), this patient's mother did not receive any prenatal care. Moreover, a folate deficiency due to a lack of prenatal vitamins is associated with an increased risk of neural tube defects. Symptoms including lower extremity paralysis and sensory deficits, bowel and bladder dysfunction, and cognitive impairment are often present from birth, as seen here. Additional evaluation, including a head MRI, should be performed because approximately 95% of patients with myelomeningocele have an associated Chiari II malformation.

Anencephaly is also a disorder of primary neurulation, and results from the failure of the anterior (rostral) neuropore closure.

B) INCORRECT:

An increase in cerebrospinal fluid pressure can cause hydrocephalus, which can occur concomitantly with myelomeningocele with a Chiari II malformation. However, hydrocephalus alone would not explain the swelling containing neural tissue on this patient's lumbosacrum. Additionally, because the fontanelles in infants are open, neurological symptoms associated with hydrocephalus may not manifest at birth. Moreover, once symptoms do present, spasticity and hyperreflexia would be expected, not hypotonia.

C) INCORRECT:

Nondisjunction of the neural tube and surface ectoderm would result in spina bifida occulta, a disorder of secondary neurulation. This nondisjunction results in failure to form the posterior vertebral arch and may result in lumbosacral swelling, as seen here. However, the cerebrospinal fluid and neural tissue are contained underneath a skin barrier in spinal bifida occulta and may only be noticeable by a dimple or tuft of hair. Moreover, most patients with spina bifida occulta are asymptomatic, and hypotonia would not be expected.

D) INCORRECT:

Defective neuronal migration at 35 months gestation can cause lissencephaly, which results in the underdevelopment of gyri and sulci in the brain. While lissencephaly can result in hypotonia, a lumbosacral swelling containing neural tissue would not be expected. Moreover, additional signs and symptoms, including microcephaly, ventriculomegaly, and craniofacial abnormalities, would be expected in a patient with lissencephaly.

E) INCORRECT:

The proliferation of totipotent germ cells can result in the formation of germ cell tumors, which can also manifest with a protrusion. However, the most common germ cell tumors in newborns are sacrococcygeal teratomas, which manifest in the sacrococcygeal region, not the lumbosacral region. Moreover, no neural tissue would be expected to be present in the protrusion.

F) INCORRECT:

A cystic dilation in the central canal suggests syringomyelia, which also causes hypotonia in the lower extremities. However, syringomyelia is most common in the cervical region, where symptoms often present in a cape-like distribution prior to manifesting in the lower extremities. Additionally, syringomyelia is not associated with a lumbosacral swelling containing neural tissue because the syrinx is most often located within the spinal cord and therefore not visible on the skin. Moreover, this condition usually manifests at 3040 years of age, rather than immediately postnatal.
questions.hint: A lumbosacral swelling that is not covered by skin, leaks CSF, and contains neural tissue is suggestive of myelomeningocele.

questions.text: A 76-year-old woman comes to the physician for a 3-day history of swelling and redness of her left lower leg. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Her temperature is 38.7C (101.7F). Examination of the left leg shows an erythematous, raised skin lesion with sharply demarcated margins. The affected skin is warm and tender to palpation. A diagnosis of cutaneous streptococcal infection is made. In addition to the upper dermis, the patient's condition is most likely to involve tissue that is derived from which of the following embryological structures?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The mesoderm gives rise to blood vessels and lymphatic vessels, including the superficial cutaneous lymphatics, which are affected in this patient with erysipelas. Other structures that are derived from the mesoderm are bones (except skull bones), muscles, connective tissue, certain organs (e.g., spleen, kidneys, adrenal cortex, gonads), the upper vagina, the serosal linings of body cavities (peritoneum, pericardium, and pleura), the notochord, the pachymeninges (dura mater), and microglial cells.
Image Description:

Adult derivatives of mesoderm (not all derivatives are shown)

Paraxial mesoderm derivatives include the vertebrae, annulus fibrosus of the intervertebral discs, and ribs.

Lateral plate mesoderm derivatives include the heart.

Intermediate mesoderm derivatives include the kidneys.

Somatic (somatopleuric) mesoderm derivatives include parietal (outer) pericardial, pleural, and peritoneal linings.

Splanchnic mesoderm derivatives include connective tissue and smooth muscle of the intestinal wall, and visceral (inner) pericardial, pleural, and peritoneal linings.

B) INCORRECT:

The neural tube gives rise to the central nervous system, retina, pineal gland, posterior pituitary, astrocytes, and oligodendrocytes. The structures involved in erysipelas are derived from a different embryonic layer.

C) INCORRECT:

The endoderm gives rise to the epithelial linings of the gastrointestinal tract, lower respiratory tract, the urethra, and the lower vagina. The structures involved in erysipelas are derived from a different embryonic layer.

D) INCORRECT:

In the skin, the epidermis, hair follicles, and sweat glands are derived from the surface ectoderm. Impetigo, an infection of the superficial layers of the epidermis, can be caused by group A streptococci and appears on an extremity or the face, as seen here. However, this condition typically affects children, not adults, and it manifests as small erythematous papules or pustules that rupture and form honey-colored crusts. Hair follicle infection (folliculitis) is typically caused by Staphylococcus spp., certain gram-negative bacteria (e.g., Pseudomonas), and certain yeast (e.g., Malassezia spp.), not by streptococci. Hidradenitis suppurativa, an infection of apocrine sweat glands, manifests with erythematous papules and pustules in the axilla, groin, or inframammary region, not the extremity. The parts of the skin involved in erysipelas are derived from a different embryonic layer.

E) INCORRECT:

In the skin of the trunk and the extremities, only melanocytes and sensory and autonomic nerves are derived from neural crest cells. The structures involved in this patient's erysipelas (i.e., upper dermis and superficial lymphatic vessels) are derived from a different embryonic layer in the trunk and extremities. Only the dermis of the head is derived from neural crest cells.
questions.hint: Erysipelas is typically caused by group A streptococci and, as seen here, manifests with an erythematous and sharply demarcated skin lesion and possibly fever. This condition is a superficial skin infection that is limited to the upper dermis and the superficial cutaneous lymphatics.

questions.text: You are seeing a 29-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 18 weeks gestation, who presents for her first prenatal visit. She works as a paralegal and lives with her husband. The pregnancy was unplanned, and she has not taken any prenatal medications or supplements. On examination, the uterus is palpated 2 inches above the umbilicus. Maternal serum -fetoprotein and both -fetoprotein and acetylcholinesterase in the amniotic fluid are elevated. Ultrasonography shows increased amniotic fluid volume. Which one of the following conditions is the most likely diagnosis in the fetus?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Anencephaly is a lethal neural tube defect (NTD) characterized by an open cranial vault and absence of the forebrain. The most important risk factor associated with NTDs is folate deficiency, either due to dietary shortage or the consumption of folic acid antagonists (e.g., valproate, carbamazepine). Because anencephaly is an open NTD that leaves the neural tube exposed, -fetoprotein (AFP) and acetylcholinesterase (AChE) can diffuse freely into the amniotic fluid and maternal serum. If both AFP and AChE are elevated in the amniotic fluid, fetal NTDs can be diagnosed with high accuracy, even if ultrasonography is inconclusive.

Key learning point: Anencephaly is an open neural tube defect characterized by elevated maternal serum and amniotic fluid -fetoprotein and acetylcholinesterase due to exposure of neural tissue.

B) INCORRECT:

Lissencephaly results from failure of neuronal cell migration, thereby inhibiting development of the gyri and sulci. This malformation is typically genetic but may also be caused by viral infections or insufficient intrauterine perfusion in early pregnancy. Lissencephaly is often diagnosed at birth or soon after via imaging; however, polyhydramnios on prenatal ultrasonography is not a characteristic finding. Moreover, lissencephaly is not associated with increased -fetoprotein and acetylcholinesterase levels in the maternal serum or amniotic fluid.

C) INCORRECT:

Myelomeningocele is a neural tube defect (NTD) that results from failure of the caudal neuropore to close. Folate deficiency, which this patient likely has (lack of prenatal supplements), is associated with an increased risk of NTDs. Myelomeningocele is an open NTD that would show increased -fetoprotein and acetylcholinesterase levels in the maternal serum or amniotic fluid, as seen here. However, this defect is not associated with polyhydramnios but is rather diagnosed based on vertebral irregularities (e.g., U-shaped vertebral body, bulging of the fetal back) on prenatal ultrasonography.

D) INCORRECT:

Spina bifida occulta is a neural tube defect (NTD) that results from failure of the caudal neuropore to close. Folate deficiency, which this patient likely has (lack of prenatal supplements), is associated with an increased risk of NTDs. However, spina bifida occulta is a closed NTD and would, therefore, not show increased -fetoprotein and acetylcholinesterase levels in the maternal serum or amniotic fluid. Moreover, this defect is not associated with polyhydramnios on prenatal ultrasonography. Spina bifida occulta is most commonly diagnosed postnatally based on typical cutaneous findings (i.e., small dimple or tuft of hair in the lumbosacral region).

E) INCORRECT:

Holoprosencephaly results from failure of the embryonic prosencephalon to separate into two cerebral hemispheres, leading to brain malformation of varying severity as well as midline craniofacial defects. The etiology is thought to be multifactorial, including both genetic (e.g., trisomy 13, mutations in sonic hedgehog signaling pathway) and environmental (e.g., alcohol and retinoic acid exposure in utero) components. Holoprosencephaly can be diagnosed on prenatal ultrasonography and fetal MRI; however, polyhydramnios is not a characteristic finding. Moreover, this defect is not associated with increased -fetoprotein and acetylcholinesterase levels in the maternal serum or amniotic fluid.
questions.hint: This fetus's condition results from failure of closure of the rostral neuropore during embryogenesis. The increased amniotic fluid volume (i.e., polyhydramnios) seen here is due to impaired fetal swallowing.

questions.text: A 2850-g (6-lb 5-oz) newborn is delivered at term to a 19-year-old primigravid woman via normal spontaneous vaginal delivery. The mother has had no prenatal care. Examination of the newborn in the delivery room shows a small, retracted jaw and hypoplasia of the zygomatic arch. This patient's condition is most likely caused by abnormal development of the structure that also gives rise to which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The facial nerve is the nerve associated with the second branchial arch. Anomalies of the second branchial arch involve the muscles of facial expression, posterior belly of the digastric, stylohyoid muscle, stapedius, derivates of the Reichert cartilage, and/or the facial nerve (e.g., underdeveloped facial muscles, facial nerve dysfunction, aplasia of the stapes with conductive hearing loss). Second branchial cleft cyst and Treacher Collins syndrome are further second branchial arch anomalies. However, neither the mandible nor the zygomatic bone is derived from the second branchial arch. The facial nerve is, therefore, unlikely to be involved here.

B) INCORRECT:

The cricothyroid muscle is a derivative of the fourth branchial arch. Anomalies of the fourth branchial arch involve the structures of the larynx and the vagal nerve (e.g., congenital laryngeal stenosis, vagal nerve dysfunction). Fourth branchial cleft cyst and double aorta are also fourth branchial arch anomalies. However, neither the mandible nor the zygomatic bone is derived from the fourth branchial arch, and this newborn has no other evidence of fourth branchial arch anomalies.

C) CORRECT:

The incus is one of the bones derived from the first branchial arch, along with the malleus, mandible, squamous temporal bone, palatine bone, zygomatic bone, vomer, and maxilla. Given this patient's hypoplastic mandible and zygomatic bone, malformations of other first branchial arch derivatives may be present, e.g., hypoplasia of the incus (manifesting as conductive hearing loss). The first branchial arch is also involved in the Pierre Robin sequence and Treacher-Collins syndrome.

The first branchial arch is associated with cranial nerve V3 and the maxillary artery. It also gives rise to the mylohyoid, anterior belly of the digastric, tensor tympani, tensor veli palatini, and all of the muscles of mastication.
Image Description:

Clockwise from top left: nerve, skeletal structure, muscle, and artery derivatives of the pharyngeal arches.

D) INCORRECT:

The greater horn of the hyoid bone is a derivative of the third branchial arch. Anomalies of the third branchial arch involve the structures of the pharynx and glossopharyngeal nerve (e.g., glossopharyngeal nerve dysfunction). Third branchial cleft cyst and internal carotid artery hypoplasia are also third branchial arch anomalies. However, neither the mandible nor the zygomatic bone is derived from the third branchial arch, and this newborn has no other evidence of third branchial arch anomalies.

E) INCORRECT:

The platysma is a derivative of the second branchial arch. Anomalies of the second branchial arch involve the muscles of facial expression, posterior belly of the digastric, stylohyoid muscle, stapedius, derivates of the Reichert cartilage, and/or the facial nerve (e.g., underdeveloped facial muscles, facial nerve dysfunction, aplasia of the stapes with conductive hearing loss). Second branchial cleft cyst and Treacher-Collins syndrome are further second branchial arch anomalies. However, neither the mandible nor the zygomatic bone is derived from the second branchial arch. The platysma is, therefore, unlikely to be involved here.
questions.hint: This patient's hypoplastic mandible and zygomatic bone suggest anomalous development of the first branchial arch.

questions.text: An otherwise healthy 1-month-old girl is brought to the physician because of a 1-day history of multiple episodes of bilious vomiting. She is diagnosed with intestinal malrotation and volvulus and undergoes emergency laparotomy. During surgery, a 3 x 3 cm cystic mass is excised from behind the umbilicus. Microscopic examination of the mass shows mature nonciliated columnar epithelium with some goblet cells lining the inner cyst wall. Dilation of which of the following structures is the most likely cause of this patient's mass?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dilation of the urachus, an embryogenic structure that connects the bladder to the yolk sac, leads to congenital anomalies such as urachal cysts. While this may manifest as an umbilical mass similar to the one seen here, urachal duct cysts tend to be asymptomatic until later in life when symptomatic complications, typically infections, may occur. In addition, the cyst would be connected to the bladder, and histologic evaluation would reveal transitional epithelium rather than intestinal epithelium.

B) INCORRECT:

A dilation of the umbilical ring occurs in the setting of umbilical hernia, which leads to protrusion and possibly incarceration of abdominal contents, resulting in intestinal obstruction, as seen in this patient. However, affected individuals present with a mass protruding through the umbilicus, not behind it. Moreover, congenital umbilical hernias are not associated with a great degree of risk of incarceration and typically resolve before 5 years of age.

C) CORRECT:

The vitelline duct is an embryonic structure that connects the yolk sac to the midgut. It usually obliterates during the 6th to 7th week of embryonic development, but partial persistence and dilation can result in the development of a retroumbilical cyst (omphalomesenteric cyst). This usually manifests with an umbilical mass, findings secondary to intestinal obstruction (as vitelline duct anomalies are associated with volvulus and intussusception), and intestinal mucosa on microscopic examination.

D) INCORRECT:

Dilation of an ovarian follicle can lead to the development of an ovarian cyst, a condition that rarely occurs in infants. Affected individuals may present with a distended abdomen and a palpable abdominal or pelvic mass, as seen in this patient. However, congenital ovarian cysts are not associated with intestinal obstruction but rather with ovarian torsion, which requires immediate surgical intervention. Subsequent histologic examination of an ovarian cysts would reveal ovarian stroma and simple cuboidal epithelium instead of intestinal epithelium.

E) INCORRECT:

Dilation of the common bile duct leads to choledochal duct cyst, a congenital anomaly that would present with jaundice, acholic stools, hepatomegaly, and a palpable mass in the right upper quadrant unlike the intestinal obstruction seen here. Moreover, histologic examination of a choledochal cyst would show biliary not intestinal epithelium.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms of intestinal obstruction (bilious vomiting) due to volvulus and histopathology findings of intestinal mucosa (mature nonciliated columnar epithelium with few goblet cells) are suggestive of a congenital anomaly similar to Meckel diverticulum.
